data.title: Pedro III of Brazil (Differently)
data.meta_description: Dom Pedro III (13 September 1909 – 5 July 1981) was the Emperor of Brazil from 1921 to 1981 and the country's fourth monarch since the establishment of the Empire. He reigned for 59 years and 8 months, only one year less than Pedro II, his great-grandfather to whom he is often compared. Pedro...
data.text:
Dom Pedro III (13 September 1909 – 5 July 1981) was the Emperor of Brazil from 1921 to 1981 and the country's fourth monarch since the establishment of the Empire. He reigned for 59 years and 8 months, only one year less than Pedro II, his great-grandfather to whom he is often compared.

Pedro III ascended the throne at age 12 in 1921 and was aided in his early years by a group called "the Second Regency" until he turned 18 in 1927, another parallel to Pedro II's life. Pedro III's reign encompassed numerous important events, including the Cold War, the construction of Brasília (the country's new capital), the creation of the Brazilian Space Program, the introduction of labour rights, the creation of Brazilian music, cinema, television and computer industries and several social movements that brought considerable change.

A much respected figure during his time, Pedro III was the Time Person of the Year in 1971, the 50th anniversary of his reign.

Marriages and Issue[]

Pedro Henrique married Princess Maria Elisabeth of Bavaria at Nymphenburg Palace, Bavaria, on 19 August 1937. They had twelve children:
